'''Main article links are in bold''' |} == 1900s == ===1900=== * February 14, 1900 â Dublin, Harcourt Street Station. A freight train overrun the buffer stops at this terminal station and ran through the end wall of the station. The locomotive was suspended over Hatch Street immediately after the collision.{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} * April 30, 1900 â [[Vaughan, Mississippi]], United States: [[Illinois Central]] passenger train No. 1, the ''Cannonball'', crashes into the rear of freight train No. 83 which is fouling the main line out of a siding at 3:52 a.m. on the Water Valley District of the Mississippi Division. Engineer of 4-6-0 ten-wheeler No. 382, [[Casey Jones|John Luther "Casey" Jones]], the only fatality, is wrongly found to be solely at fault by the ensuing investigation. The accident spawns the vastly popular "[[Ballad of Casey Jones]]" by roundhouse worker and friend of the deceased, [[Wallace Saunders]], and the root theme for a [[Grateful Dead]] song titled "[[Casey Jones]]".{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * May 22, 1900 â [[Oakland, California]], United States: [[Southern Pacific Railroad|Southern Pacific]] passenger local is mistakenly switched into a narrow-gauge track. The iron rail curls up beneath the locomotive, flipping it over and killing the engineer and fireman. The engineer, Frank Shaw, is last seen shutting down the locomotive's steam and is credited with saving the lives of the passengers, none of whom are killed or seriously injured.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * June 16, 1900 â [[Slough]]. [[Great Western Railway]] express train from Paddington runs into rear of local train at Slough station, killing 5 people.Robertson, Kevin, "Odd Corners of the G.W.R.", The History Press, Stroud, England, 2010, ISBN 978-0-7509-3458-9, page 134 * August 13, 1900 â [[Baltimore, Maryland]], United States: [[Baltimore & Ohio]] 2-8-2 Mikado locomotive and tender are knocked off the [[Carrollton Viaduct]] at [[Gwynns Falls]] by a side-strike and land inverted in the stream below.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * September 2, 1900 â [[Hatfield, Pennsylvania]], United States: Going from Souderton to Philadelphia, a [[milk train]] collided with an excursion train, killing 13 people and injuring 45.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} ===1902=== [[File:Railway accident near Brindisi 1902.jpg|thumb|200px|Train Wreck Brindisi Italy 1902]] * January 8, 1902 â [[New York City, New York]], United States: A stopped [[New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad|New Haven]] express train from [[South Norwalk, Connecticut|South Norwalk]] is rear-ended in the Park Avenue tunnel by a [[New York Central]] [[White Plains, New York|White Plains]] local, due to smoke and snow obscuring signals. Fifteen persons were killed and 36 injured, the worst rail accident in New York City history. The accident inspired the State Legislature to pass a law the next year prohibiting steam operation on the [[New York and Harlem Railroad|Park Avenue line]] south of the [[Harlem River]].{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * December 6, 1902 â [[City of Halifax|Halifax, N.S.]], Six persons were killed in a wreck on the Inter-Colonial, the Canadian Government railway, at noon to-day near Belmont Station, seventy miles from Halifax. The Canadian Pacific express for Montreal rolled down an embankment, completely wrecking the locomotive, the postal, express, and baggage cars and several passenger cars.[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B02E2DB1E30E132A25754C0A9649D946397D6CF TRAIN WRECK KILLS SIX, December 6, 1902] * December 20, 1902 â Byron Springs, Contra Costa County, California, United States: The south-bound ''Stockton Flyer'' crashed into the rear of the disabled ''Los Angeles Owl'', killing 20 and injuring 25. Both trains had departed from Oakland, California. Prominent California lawyer [[Frank Hamilton Short]] and journalist [[Chester Harvey Rowell]] were passengers on board the Owl. Neither was injured.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} *[[Frankfurt am Main]], Germany: Serious [[buffer stop]] collision inspires development of [[Rawie]] range of energy-absorbing buffer stops.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} ===1903=== [[File:Old97Wreck.jpg|thumb|200px|The aftermath of the [[Wreck of the Old 97]].]] [[File:Purdue Wreck.jpg|thumb|200px| The first coach of the Big Four special, where the Purdue football team was seated, lies crushed between the second coach and a coal tender.]] * January 28, 1903, 3:30 AM â In what was later called the '''[[Esmond Train Wreck]]''' 14 people, including the engineers of both trains, are killed when the Benson, Arizona bound ''Crescent City Express'' (No. 8) collides head-on with the Tucson, Arizona bound ''Pacific Coast Express'' (No. 7). A communication error was determined to be the cause of the wreckâNight operator Clough is said to have admitted that he did not deliver a second order to Conductor Parker, which would superseded the previous order for the ''Crescent City Express'' (No.8) to proceed to Vails Station. Had the second order been delivered, it would have allowed the ''Pacific Coast Express'' (No.7) to pass unscathed."22 Dead; 45 Injured: The Estimated Casualties of the Southern Pacific Catastrophe Yesterday", ''Arizona Daily Star'', January 29, 1903"Story of the Esmond Wreck Vividly Told", ''Arizona Daily Star'', February 1, 1903http://homepage.mac.com/icafe/RitaRanch/TrainWreck.html * July 27, 1903 â '''[[Glasgow St Enoch rail accident]]''', Scotland: 16 killed when a train crashed into the buffers. * August 10, 1903 â '''[[Paris MÃ©tro train fire]]''', France: electric fire at the [[Paris MÃ©tro]] Couronnes station, 84 killed. This led to the design of low-voltage control circuit for electric multiple-unit cars and better lighting in the MÃ©tro stations. * September 27, 1903 â '''[[Wreck of the Old 97]]''', [[Danville, Virginia]], United States: Southbound [[Southern Railway (US)|Southern Railway]] [[passenger train]] No. 97, en route from Monroe, Virginia to Spencer, North Carolina, derails at Stillhouse Trestle near Danville and plunges into the ravine below. Eleven are killed including the engine crew and a number of Railway Post Office clerks in the [[railway post office|mail car]] right behind the tender. The wreck inspired a famous ballad, ''The Wreck of the Old 97'', the 1920s recording of which by country singer [[Vernon Dalhart]] is sometimes cited as the American recording industry's first million-seller. * October 31, 1903 â The '''[[Purdue Wreck]]''', [[Indianapolis, Indiana, USA]]: A [[Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago, and St. Louis Railroad]] football special carrying the [[Purdue University]] football team and fans to the annual [[Indiana University]] / Purdue University football game collides with a coal train. Seventeen passengers in the first coach are killed, including 14 members of the football team. * December 23, 1903 â '''[[Connellsville train wreck]]''' near [[Connellsville, Pennsylvania]] kills 66 people as the [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]]'s ''Dequesne Limited'' runs into timber dropped from a freight train. === 1904 === * February 9, 1904 â [[Sand Point, Ontario]] [[head-on collision]]; 13 killed & 19 injured.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * August 7, 1904 â '''[[Eden Train Wreck]]''', near Eden Station north of [[Pueblo, Colorado]], United States: Train caught in bridge [[washaway]]; 97 known dead; 14 missing * August 14, 1904 â [[Shelby County, Ohio]], United States; Collision of 2 electric trains. 4 killed/30 injured.[http://ohshelby.ancestralsites.com/pics0049.html Shelby County, OHio] * August 31, 1904 â [[Richmond, Quebec]]: [[head-on collision]] between a special train from Montreal to Sherbrooke, and Passenger Train No. 5 from Island Pond, Vermont; 9 killed, including Member of Parliament [[Jean Baptiste Blanchet]], and 23 injured.[http://www.lecourrier.qc.ca/edition/2007-04-25/607ch3q.html][http://www3.gendisasters.com/train-wrecks-accidents/15493/richmond-qb-train-collision-sep-1904] * September 24, 1904 â '''[[New Market train wreck]]''', [[Jefferson County, Tennessee]], United States: Two [[Southern Railway (US)|Southern Railway]] passenger trains, the ''Carolina Special'' and Local train No. 15, collide [[Head-on collision|head-on]] near [[New Market, Tennessee]] near Hodges Switch when the crew of the local, a three-car consist, fails to take the siding to allow the ''Carolina Special'' to pass. The impact knocks the boilers off of both locomotives and the engine on the local is catapulted onto the first three wooden coaches of the ''Special''. The impact causes the boilers of both locomotives to explode and the cars of the local passenger train to telescope. At the time, it was the worst wreck of its kind to ever occur in North America. Between 56 and 113 killed. * October 10, 1904 â [[Warrensburg, Missouri]], United States: An eastbound [[Missouri Pacific Railroad]] passenger train, en route to the [[Louisiana Purchase Exposition|St. Louis World's Fair]], collides head-on with a freight train. Thirty people are killed.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * December 23, 1904 â [[Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire]], England, United Kingdom. [[Derailment]]. The 0245 am [[Great Central Railway]] express newspaper train from [[London Marylebone]] to [[Manchester]] derailed as it approached [[Aylesbury railway station]] from the south, approximately at the location of the junction with the [[Great Western Railway]] branch from [[Princes Risborough]]. Its speed carried the wreckage along the platforms of the station, and four of those on board the train, including the driver and fireman of the engine, and another driver and fireman travelling as passengers back to their home depot were killed. Two others, both railway staff, were seriously injured. A southbound train, ex Manchester, then collided with the wreckage at low-speed causing damage to rolling stock but no further casualties.http://www.railwaysarchive.co.uk/documents/BoT_Aylesbury1904.pdf ===1905=== * July 27, 1905 â '''[[Hall Road rail accident]]''', [[Liverpool]], [[Lancashire]] to Southport line, 21 killed. * 7 August 1905 â between [[Spremberg]] and [[Schleife]] on ([[Berlin-GÃ¶rlitz railway]]), 19 people killed and 40 seriously injured in head-on crash as a result of an error by a dispatcher.{{cite book|first=Hans-Joachim|last= Ritzau|coauthors= HÃ¶rstel, JÃ¼rgen; Wolski, Thomas |title= Schatten der Eisenbahngeschichte (Shadow on railway history)|year= 1997 |isbn=978-3-921304-36-5|page=117 |language=German}} * September 1, 1905 â '''[[Witham rail crash]]''', [[Essex]]. 11 killed and 50 injured. * September 11, 1905 â '''[[Ninth Avenue derailment]]''', [[Manhattan]], [[New York]]. 13 killed and 48 seriously injured when a southbound train on the [[IRT Ninth Avenue Line]] was erroneously switched onto the 53rd Street curve to the [[IRT Sixth Avenue Line|Sixth Avenue line]]. ===1906=== * June 30, 1906 â '''[[Salisbury rail crash]]''', [[Salisbury]], England: Racing express train derails, then collides with a milk train on a sharp curve, 28 killed (24 passengers, 4 crew). * August 13, 1906 â [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], Four boys were killed on the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks by an ''Eastbound Express''. The accident occurred where three levels of tracks crossed over Broad Street.The New York Times, Published August 14, 1906, "Fast Train Kills 4 Boys" * September 18, 1906 â [[Dover, Oklahoma|Dover, Oklahoma Territory]]: Bridge across the [[Cimarron River (Arkansas River)|Cimarron River]] collapses beneath a [[Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad|Rock Island]] train bound for [[Fort Worth, Texas]] from [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]]. The bridge was a temporary structure unable to withstand the pressure of debris and high water. Replacement with a permanent structure had been delayed by the railroad for financial reasons. Number of deaths is uncertain; estimates range from 4 to over 100.{{cite web| author=Kite, Steven | url=http://www.library.okstate.edu/scua/exhibit/oaa/20sep00.htm | title=Corporate Greed Leads to Death in Oklahoma Territory |work= Oklahoma Audio Almanac| publisher=Oklahoma State University Library | date=September 20, 2000 |accessdate=May 18, 2010}}{{cite web| url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/D/DO011.html | title=Dover | work=Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture | publisher=Oklahoma Historical Society|accessdate=May 18, 2010}}{{cite book |last1=Goins| first1=Charles Robert| last2=Goble |first2=Danney| title=Historical Atlas of Oklahoma |page=119 |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3482-6|year=2006}}{{cite web|url=http://www.doversociety.org/DofD-Oklahoma.html| last=Sencicle | first=Lorraine | title=Dover Oklahoma | date=January 2008 | work=The Daughters of Dover: Dover around the world|location=Dover, England| publisher=The Dover Society | accessdate=May 22, 2010}} * September 19, 1906 â '''[[Grantham rail accident]]''', [[Grantham]], England: Evening sleeping-car and mail train from London to Edinburgh derailed, no definite cause ever established, 14 killed. * September 21, 1906 â [[Napanee, Ontario]], Canada: A [[Grand Trunk Railway]] [[passenger train]] hits a stopped freight train at a crossover in [[Napanee, Ontario]]; the engineer stayed at the controls trying to slow his train as much as possible. He was the only fatality. The train's passengers later erected a monument in the engineer's honor.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * October 28, 1906 â '''[[1906 Atlantic City train wreck]]''': On the newly-electrified [[West Jersey and Seashore Railroad]] a Sunday afternoon passenger train, traveling towards [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]] at forty miles per hour, derails on a draw (swing) bridge over a deep tidal channel. The train bumps along the ties for {{convert|150|ft|m}} before departing the bridge and plunging into deep water. Fifty-three die in what will remain the worst U.S. drawbridge accident until the [[Newark Bay, New Jersey rail accident]] of September 15, 1958. * November 12, 1906 â [[Detroit, Michigan]], United States: A train of the [[Michigan Central Railroad]] drives through the stub end of the Michigan Central's Third Street passenger yard and into the station itself.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * December 28, 1906 â '''[[Elliot Junction rail accident]]''', Scotland; 22 killed. * December 30, 1906 â '''[[1906 Washington DC train wreck]]''', United States: A [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]] locomotive running at full speed plows into a passenger train that had just pulled out of Terra Cotta (now [[Fort Totten (Washington, D.C.)|Fort Totten]]) Station along the B&O Metropolitan Branch, telescoping the rear cars and taking the lives of fifty-three passengers. === 1907 === * January 16, 1907 â Thingley Junction, [[Chippenham]]. Head-on collision between two [[Great Western Railway]] locomotives, River class 2-4-0 No. 70 "Dart" and [[GWR 2301 Class|Dean Goods]] No 2448. Both locos are badly damaged and are cut up on site.Robertson, Kevin, "Odd Corners of the G.W.R.", The History Press, Stroud, England, 2010, ISBN 978-0-7509-3458-9, page 133 [[File:Train Wreck of 1907, Canaan, NH.jpg|thumb|1907 accident in New Hampshire]] * September 15, 1907 â [[Canaan, New Hampshire]], United States: Quebec to Boston Express wreck; 25 people killed, with nearly 39 injured. The southbound express (No. 30), heavily loaded with passengers returning from the Sherbrooke Fair, collided at 4:26 a.m. on a foggy Sunday morning with a northbound [[Boston & Maine Railroad]] freight train (No. 267). The accident, {{convert|4|mi|km}} north of Canaan Station, was "due to a mistake in train dispatcher's orders." On March 17, 1907 Chas Anderson was killed due to an accident while working on the railroad. He left behind a wife Jennie and 3 children Otto, Loren, and Francis Anderson. * October 15, 1907 â '''[[Shrewsbury rail accident]]''', [[Shrewsbury]], England: Evening sleeping-car and mail train from Manchester to the west of England derailed, probably due to driver error, 18 killed. * September 28, 1907 â '''[[Newport rail accident]]''', [[Newport]], Wales: 1 killed. ===1908=== * April 20, 1908 â '''[[Sunshine train disaster]]''', [[Melbourne]], Australia: Rear-end collision, kills 44 and injures around 400. * May 21, 1908 â [[Kontich]], Belgium: 40 people are killed as a train crashes into a stationary passenger train in the railway station of [[Kontich]].{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} === 1909 === * January 14, 1909 - a train from Paris to [[Le Mans]] collides with another train. [[Orville Wright|Orville]] and [[Katharine Wright]] were amongst the passengers.[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200048.html?tracked=1 ''Flight'', 23 January 1909, p50] * April 12, 1909 â [[Gary, Indiana]], United States: A westbound [[South Shore Line (NICTD)|Chicago Lake Shore & South Bend Railroad]] train runs past a meet point and causes a [[head-on collision]] with the eastbound train, injuring 47 passengers.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * April 21, 1909 â [[Cardiff]], Wales: Fitter incorrectly assembles locomotive's safety valves. [[Boiler explosion|Boiler explodes]] in shed, killing three.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * June 19, 1909 â [[Burns Harbor, Indiana]], United States: An eastbound [[South Shore Line (NICTD)|Chicago Lake Shore & South Bend Railroad]] train runs past a meet point and causes a [[head-on collision]] with the westbound train. 12 were killed, 52 injured.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * September 4, 1909 â [[Ellwood City, Pennsylvania]], United States: A westbound [[Baltimore & Ohio]] train is derailed when tracks are deliberately sabotaged along the banks of the Beaver River. Although two men were arrested the next day, they were later released and the crime was never solved. 3 were killed, 20 injured.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} ==1910s== ===1910=== * January 21, 1910 â '''[[Spanish River derailment]]''' [[Northern Ontario]], Canada: [[Canadian Pacific Railway]]'s westbound ''Soo Express'' derails while crossing the bridge at [[Spanish River (Ontario)|Spanish River]]. 44 people die, many more are injured. * March 1, 1910 â The '''[[Wellington, Washington avalanche]]''': in [[Wellington, Washington|Wellington]], near the [[Cascade Tunnel]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], United States, approximately 100 are killed when a snow [[avalanche]] pushes two trains off a cliff. The trains had been stopped at a mountain depot; the passenger train halted by an avalanche ahead of it, and then trapped by an avalanche behind it. Passengers and rail employees mostly stayed on board the stopped trains, which were subsequently struck squarely by another avalanche. * March 21, 1910 â '''[[Green Mountain train wreck]]''', Iowa, United States: A [[Rock Island Railroad]] passenger train traveling derailed, killing 52 passengers and severely injuring scores of others. * August 15, 1910 â Two trolley cars of the [[Gettysburg Electric Railway]] collided near [[Devil's Den]], ejecting people onto rocks (1 fatality). A similar collision occurred during the [[1913 Gettysburg reunion]], and trolley incidents on the [[Gettysburg Battlefield]] included failed tracks, sabotage, and lightning strikes. * December 24, 1910 â '''[[Hawes Junction train disaster]]''', [[Cumbria]], England: Busy signalman forgets about light engines on main line, and the express was signaled onto it, killing 12. ===1911=== * 1911 â [[Port Glasgow]], John Sanderson, ran over by Goods train.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * January 23, 1911 â '''[[Pontypridd railway accident]]'''. Collision between a passenger train and coal train on the Taff Vale Railway at Hopkinstown. 11 killed. * May 29, 1911 â '''[[Indianola train wreck]]'''. Collision between two passenger trains at [[Indianola, Nebraska]] killing 18 and injuring 32.{{cite web| url=http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?websearch&site=dot_railroads| title=INVESTIGATIONS OF RAILROAD ACCIDENTS 1911–1993| date=October 18, 1912| publisher=Interstate Commerce Commission Report| at=File Number 1-B| accessdate=June 2, 2011 }} * July 11, 1911 â outside of [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]]: The [[Federal Express (passenger train)|''Federal Express'']], carrying the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] baseball team on a trip from [[Philadelphia]] to [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], plunges down an {{convert|18|ft|m|sing=on}} embankment, killing 14 passengers.[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/baseballlibrary/chronology/1911JULY.stm#day11 Tuesday, July 11th] from BaseballLibrary.com No one from the team is killed. * August 13, 1911 â [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]]: The [[Pennsylvania Railroad]]'s ''Penn Flyer'' derails at Fort Wayne. Almost immediately, the derailed equipment is struck by an oncoming freight train, killing four and injuring 57. * August 25, 1911 â [[Manchester (town), New York|Manchester, New York]]: Two cars connected to the [[Lehigh Valley Railroad]]'s Number 4 train derail near a bridge in Manchester, New York due to a broken rail. The cars plummet {{convert|45|ft|m}} into the stream below. Nearly 30 people are killed and dozens more injured in the wreck.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} ===1912=== * 1912 â [[MalmslÃ¤tt]], Sweden: A train runs into a stationary passenger train, leaving 22 dead and 12 injured.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * March 18, 1912 - [[San Antonio, Texas]] â Largest [[boiler explosion]] in US history at the [[Southern Pacific Railroad|Southern Pacific]] [[roundhouse]] in San Antonio, Texas.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * July 4, 1912 â '''[[Corning train wreck]]''' - [[Corning (city), New York|Corning, New York]], United States: A [[Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad]] express train crashes into the rear of a stalled excursion train near Corning on [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]], killing 39. * July 5, 1912 â Between [[Ligonier, Pennsylvania|Ligonier]] and Wilpen in [[Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania]], United States: A passenger coach being pushed by a locomotive collides with an oncoming freight train, killing 26 on the [[Ligonier Valley Railroad]].{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * August 29, 1912 â a light engine collides with a rake of nine carriages at {{stnlnk|Vauxhall}}. One passenger is killed and 43 injured.{{cite journal |last1=Brodrick |first1=Nick |year= |title=LSWR "lavatory brake thrird" |journal=Steam Railway |publisher=Bauer Media |volume= |issue=375, 30 April - 27 May 2010 |pages=p56 |url= |doi= }} * September 17, 1912 â '''[[Ditton Junction rail crash]]'''. Driver misreads signals resulting in 15 deaths. ===1913=== * January 1, 1913 â [[West Virginia]], United States: A too heavy locomotive goes onto the [[Guyandotte River]] bridge, which is being repaired. Bridge collapses and [http://www3.gendisasters.com/west-virginia/6074/guyandotte-wv-train-plunges-through-bridge-jan-1913 7] {engineer and 6 workmen} are killed. * June 25, 1913 â [http://www3.gendisasters.com/train-wrecks-accidents/11570/ottawa-on-eight-die-in-train-crash-june-1913 Ottawa train accident], Canada: A train heavily loaded with immigrants derails near [[Ottawa]]. [http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A01E6D6103CE633A25755C2A9609C946296D6CF Spreading rails sends two immigrant cars into river]. 8 die and approximately 50 are injured. * July 26, 1913 â [[Bramminge train accident]], Denmark: A train derails near [[Bramming]] due to heat-stressed rails. 15 die and about 80 are injured. * July 30, 1913 â [[Tyrone, Pennsylvania]], United States: Two [[Pennsylvania Railroad]] trains collide in front of the station at [[Tyrone]] when the engineer of ''Chicago Mail'' train No. 13 runs through a stop signal, and his locomotive crushes the rear coach of train No. 15, the ''Pittsburgh Express''. The first postal car of the moving train is thrown across the track into the front of the depot. The engineer is killed and 163 passengers are injured. Collision occurred at 2:38 pm. All-steel cars on both trains are credited with the low mortality.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * September 1, 1913 â '''[[1913 Ais Gill rail accident|Ais Gill rail crash]]''', [[Cumbria]], England: Distracted engine crew pass signals at danger, and crash into train stalled on gradient. 14 killed, 38 seriously injured * December 28, 1913 â [[New Windsor, New York]]: Locomotive of northbound express passenger train of the [[West Shore RR]] runs down and kills [[Charles Cavanaugh]], retired veteran Hudson River brick barge captain, age 66, who had become hard of hearing, and was walking on the right-of-way.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} ===1914=== * 1914 â '''[[Exeter crossing loop collision]]''', [[New South Wales]], Australia. A freight train entering the Exeter station collided head-on with a mail train being removed from the track in anticipation of the arrival of the freight train. Fourteen people were killed in the accident. * June 18, 1914 â Baddengorm Burn, [[Carr Bridge]], Scotland: Cloudburst washed away the foundations of a bridge, which collapsed as a passenger train crossed it. The train split in two, with one coach falling into the burn, drowning 5 people.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * August 5, 1914 - Neosho, Missouri, there was a head-end collision between a gasoline motor car and a passenger train on the Kansas City Southern Railway near Tipton Ford, Mo., resulting in the death of 38 passengers and 5 employees and the injury of 34 passengers and 4 employees. The collision caused the pipes and tanks carrying the gasoline to burst, permitting its ignition, at once enveloping the entire car in flames, making the work of rescue impossible. Many of the passengers were burnt beyond recognition. ===1915=== [[File:Fairfield Connecticut Train Wreck 1915.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Train wreck-Fairfield Connecticut 1915]] * January 1, 1915 â '''[[Ilford rail crash (1915)|Ilford rail crash]]''', The 7:06 express from [[Clacton]] to London passed both distant and home signals. The express crashed into the side of a local train that had been crossing the tracks. 10 killed, 500 injured (including those reporting shock). * May 22, 1915 â In the '''[[Quintinshill rail crash]]''' near [[Gretna Green]], Scotland, a troop train collides with a stationary passenger train and another passenger train crashes into the wreckage, which also involves two stationary freight trains. The passenger cars are wooden-bodied and a serious fire ensues. The second train was forgotten by a careless signalman following improper operating practices during a shift change at this busy location. This is the deadliest railway accident in British history, with 226 fatalities and 246 people injured. * August 14, 1915 â '''[[Weedon rail crash (1915)|Weedon rail crash]]''' Express train derails after the track on the up main line is forced out of alignment by a detached coupling rod from a passing locomotive heading a down express. 10 passengers killed, 21 injured. * December 17, 1915 â '''[[St Bedes Junction rail crash]]''', passenger train collides with banking engine in thick fog, 19 killed. ===1916=== * November 7, 1916 â [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]: A crowded passenger car of the [[Boston Elevated]] Street Railway plunges through an open drawbridge into [[Fort Point Channel]], just outside the [[South Station]] terminal. Fifty are killed.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} * November 31, 1916 â [[Herceghalom]], Austria-Hungary: The train arriving from the funeral of [[Franz Joseph I]] crashes into the fast train to [[Graz]]. 71 people killed.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} ===1917=== * January 3, 1917 â '''[[Ratho rail crash]]''': The unsafe use of hand signals results in 12 deaths. * January 13, 1917 â '''[[Ciurea rail disaster]]''' at [[Ciurea]], Romania: A passenger train overloaded with soldiers and refugees runs away down a bank between [[BÃ¢rnova]] and Ciurea, derailing at Ciurea station after being diverted onto a loop line. Union.
